Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Lots of circuit work!
Circuitry (RLC), optics, extreme patience

This class provided good practice with a variety of circuit components and the applications of relevant electrical laws in practice. The course also included a range of other enjoyable and interesting labs on topics such as magnetic flux and light.
I learned about circuits and waves.
How to ask questions and struggle through things I did not have any prior knowledge of.
How to set up a circuit.
I did not learn much in this class besides how to work a lot of physics devices.
PHYS 166L was a really wonderful complement to PHYS 171.

PHYS 166L helped me in grasping abstract concepts that were taught in PHYS 181. Many of the concepts in the lecture course were difficult to understand, but in lab, you assign some physical significance to it.
How to think about physical relationships using equations
Applications of physics through experimentation.
I got to really understand how circuits worked, as well as learn things not learned in my specific lecture (optics).
I grew to understand what a lot of the circuits we talk about theoretically look like in the real world.
How to write succinctly, how to pick out which parts of the handout are actually going to be quizzed
It's a nice practical complement to the topics taught in PHYS 181.
How to set up simple circuits, basics of induction and optics.
I learned more physics lab skills and how to use lab equipment to demonstrate principles of E&M.

This class is truly dismal. Not only is it boring, tedious, and time-consuming, it also has little no educational value. The lab sequence and topics are not at all aligned with the lecture course (at least not Physics 181), and so students are forced to learn completely new topics by reading convoluted lab packets prior to experiments. Thankfully, the lab procedures are usually pretty easy to follow but the vast majority of the conceptual learning is lost on at least 75% of the class.
You learn about how the circuits and things you learn in lab apply in real life examples. Also, you learn about optics which is something not mentioned in class.
I learned how to perform various experiments to test and prove physical laws and concepts. I developed my laboratory journaling skills and report writing skills.
I learned about basic physics concepts and how to be more confident in myself as a scientist.
Learned lab techniques for E&M and optics.
How to conduct various types of physics experiments and write concise lab reports -  learned how to use oscilloscopes, volt meters, function generators and more.
A continuation of first semester physics lab. It's fine, I found it a lot better than last semester. The labs are intereting.
I learned how to use some equipment and got hands-on experience with circuits and other physical mechanisms.

I learned how to use various electrical equipment and measurement tools, as well as several theoretical concepts related to electricity and light. I got to see how a lot of these fundamental concepts and basic circuits could be expanded to more complex real-world applications.
basic lab practices.
Taught me a lot about how and where physics is applied in the real world. Really good class!

I learned some material about signals, frequencies, circuits, resistors, capacitors, inductors, optics, and diffraction. I learned how to use an oscilloscope, how to build circuits, and some other methods in physics lab. I was better able to see how these topics in physics lab connected to lecture and also to other physics application (Fourier transforms were very applicable to biophysics, which I was taking this semester).
Use of physics lab equipment (oscilloscope, etc.)
How to construct circuits, use an oscilloscope, measure and analyze data with Logger Pro, a bit of Fourier Analysis and optics
I don't even know what I learned; this course was kind of all over the place. You spend a lot of time making FFT graphs of obscure wave signals, making random circuits, telescopes, biologic, etc.
Better physical understanding of circuits and the way they work.
Applied basic E+M and optics knowledge in lab setting. Not much new materials after 260 (or 180+181 probably).
This class fulfills a requirement.  I gained pretty minimal knowledge but that's simply how the class is designed.
physics equipment
Learned how to work with Oscilloscopes, LoggerPro data collection, Multimeters and circuit elements.
Basic physics laboratory skills for circuits and electronics.
This lab taught me about the topics taught in lecture and I really liked the professors.
This course was great alongside PHYS 171. It really helped me better understand circuits and other concepts by doing them. I learned how to put together a circuit.
Electrical circuits, magnetism, electromagnetism, simple optics.

I built a lot of practical laboratory skills, as well as insight and knowledge of a lot of physics concepts. I learned how to safely use electronic equipment and analyze a broad variety of electrical signals.
This lab course taught me how to use different equipment in a physics setting, such as the oscilloscope and different circuit elements.
I learned (somewhat) how to assemble circuits and analyze them using a variety of tools like oscilloscopes and multimeters.
Practical applications of E&M concepts (RC and LRC circuits, induction, etc.), physics relations to medicine
This course made me much more comfortable with circuits and their various components. It was also very interesting to learn how to use an oscilloscope and how to measure signals.

This course taught me insights into physics 2 concepts related to electricity, magnetism, and waves. I learned how to use make circuits and use oscilloscopes and logger pro to create graphical representations of physical phenomena.
basic physics lab methods, i guess
none
How to apply topics from lecture to a practical application.
I learned how to manipulate electronic equipment to analyze electrical signals. I studied properties of light and optics. I reinforced physics lecture principles in the laboratory.
Nothing that we will use practically unless youre going into mechanical engineering
An in depth knowledge of circuits, optics, and also how to use the proper technology and tools in physics circuit work.
Very little. I will, however, concede that I learned how to use an oscilloscope and the basics of optics.
I learnt various techniques in physics to study physical laws.
I learned how to work in a physics lab and how to use certain equipment.
basic lab practices
I learned how to problem solve using equations and applying known concepts to new experiments.
I learned how to utilize equipment pertaining to electricity and magnetism in the physics laboratory.
This lab course taught me skills in statistics and physics and how to apply concepts learned in class to our everyday lives.
Learned a lot about circuits
I learned about practical applications of electricity concepts. Also good medical applications.
I learned more about electricity and magnetism than I ever thought possible, plus applications of these in real life and parallels in biology.
I learned how some of the things in phys 180 work in a more intuitive way
I learned how to use basic lab equipments that are relevant to the E&M unit.
How to draw circuit diagrams and use an oscilloscope. That's about it.
I had the chance to try different instruments - oscilloscope, LoggerPro, motion detector, etc.
I did not think I developed any skills, except maybe how to make circuit .
Very little
A lot of circuits and signal analysis.

I learned about the equipment and protocols necessary to use the oscilloscope to measure signals generated by a signal generator or broadcast through a cable, and how to interpret these signals. The course clarified and made tangible concepts about circuits from lecture. I also learned a bit about optics and physical ways of visualizing these concepts.
We learned about circuits, optics, wave interference, pendulums, and other introductory physics concepts in a laboratory setting.
basic physics lab for E and M, learned how to build circuits and use circuit elements
Learn a lot about physics lab equipment, how to use LoggerPro, and fundamental concepts of waves, optics, electricity and magnetism.
I think I learned how to use an oscilloscope and how to make a telescope.
how to better operate computers, LoggerPro, the oscilloscope, and function generator
This course helped me understand how we can observe basic principles of electromagnetism using simple lab set ups.
I learned more about the general equipment needed to study physics.
I learned about optics, circuits, and electromagnetic induction. I also learned how to use a oscilloscope, multimeter, and LoggerPro voltage probe.
practical measurement of circuitry, applications of E&M concepts
I learned how to work with magnets and circuits on an experimental level.
This was a good counterpart to Phys 171, giving a hands-on real-life representation of the theory in Phys 171.
This course was actually pretty fun and I learned a lot about physics through hands-on lab work. I also developed skills with a variety of types of equipment.
Honestly, the only new skill I acquired through this course was using LoggerPro. Otherwise, the same material was taught to me in the physics lecture or through solely watching videos.
Practiced using an oscilloscope and working with LoggerPro.

I learned how to conceptualize and apply the information I was learning in my physics lecture course to tangible experiments with real-world implications. This course taught me how to handle and operate many different instruments utilized in physics laboratories.
I gained some practical skills in physics labs.
Physical understanding of physics concepts and a greater appreciation for physics at work.
physics lab
I gained a thorough understanding of various electricity and magnetism concepts through the lab experiments.
I learned how to figure out things I have no idea about.
We learned about many physics concepts and how to measure them in a lab setting.
We learned how to construct and work with many kinds of circuits and how to use all of the instruments that are involved.

I didn't like how opaque "Insight" point grading was. Additionally, it ends up being that most of your grade is due to the final, which puts a lot of emphasis on a relatively small part of the course.

The hands-on experiments are actually pretty fun! This lab helped me understand circuits much more than I did before.

Strengths: interesting topic choices overall, good alignment with physics lecture

Weaknesses: unencouraging and often patronizing demeanor of male TAs and instructors, lack of instruction/demonstration in handouts (EX: breadboard circuitry)

I would recommend that all male TAs receive training on how to speak to students in a way that is neither patronizing nor discouraging (in fact, achieving the complete opposite would be nice). One of the TAs, during a practical practice session on Wednesday night, answered questions in a way that was so brusque and condescending that I considered leaving halfway through. A friend of mine felt the same. This is a systemic issue that I've noticed in the physics department and should not be acceptable, as it negates any of the positive effects of learning the content.

I think the course should be redesigned in a way that it is aligned with what we are learning in class. Personally, I found it easy because I have a greater background in physics but students who were seeing these concepts for the first time found it a bit hard. Ultimately, it's doable though. Also wish I could have more guidance on the insights section in lab reports- I felt it was so random and I was just guessing what to write.

This course was engaging and quite fair overall with the grading. A lot of the theoretical questions towards the end of the labs were interesting, although I often wished that the labs went into greater depth, particularly in the math.

Strengths: There was always a TA or instructor to help clarify confusing concepts.

Weaknesses: There was a lot of assumed knowledge for this course, that many people did not have, because this course did not line up well with the physics lecture.  I understand why the two courses maybe can't line up, but I think that instead of just assuming we would be able to understand all of the complexities of circuits, etc, it would be useful to have a small lecture before we began to go over key concepts. Our TA did this in some form, especially towards the end, but I think that they could have been more in-depth, since some of these topics can be very confusing. The pre-lab handouts introduced many new topics, so I think having a chance to discuss them in class would have been useful. The heavy focus on the oscilloscope was frustrating, and maybe we could have used further instruction on it, to understand what we were doing as we tried to get a clear picture of the waves we were studying.

The material is not covered in the lecture 181 until after we do it in lab so much of lab time is spent answering questions.  There was not a single lab where I did not ask a question on every part and most groups around me had to do the same thing.  This caused lab to be very long sometimes when it otherwise would have been streamlined if we had more background knowledge.

Strengths: Only meets for 3 hours, experiments usually finish early. Teachers (especially Sid Cahn) are always very helpful and can explain concepts thoroughly.

Weaknesses: The lab handouts sound a little condescending and the application of this class is relatively low.
More use with oscilloscope.
This class was tedious and time consuming and should count for 1 credit.

Strengths) Really reasonable experiments, workloads, and requirements. 

Weaknesses) Your experience depends largely on which TA you get. Sheridan, my TA however, was amazing. When we had substitutes because Sheridan was not able to make it, the class was poorly taught and confusing. Final exam generally much harder than anything done in the lab.

I think the course could be improved by better supporting information before hand. Many of the labs were difficult to understand before doing them in lab. The reason for this is because sometimes the lab course would not overlap with the lecture course so the only exposure we'd have to the topics would be a few pages in the course packet, which was not enough. I believe converting some of the information into a digital format with a lecturer and demos would be helpful in preparing students before lab.

Another improvement that could be made is in the grading for "insight" in lab reports. After taking PHYS 165 and 166, I've learned that the "insight" that is asked for isn't really insight but more so bullshit. If you're good at bullshitting, you'll get full insight points. While this discovery was good for my grades, it was a little disheartening to know that actual insight and understandings of the topics isn't what is sought.

Another improvement would be better coordination with the lecture courses. As previously mentioned there were times when lab would expose us to topics before lecture, yet try to build off of the topics it assumed we had learned. Frequently TFs and instructors would ask us if we had covered it in lecture already and I think that's something that should be communicated within the department beforehand. The PHYS 181 lecturer herself mentioned herself that she wishes she could organize a lab course that made more sense to her lecture course.

The course has good intentions in that it intends to encourage students to learn to solve problems and draw relations between different physical phenomena. Still, I found that the lab handouts were often riddled with more questions than they were answers, making it extremely difficult for students with minimal physics background to keep up with other students (especially in cases where the material was "presented" before it was present in physics lecture). The result? A large majority of students end up completing each lab after spending hours waiting for their section's TA to come around and answer their questions throughout the lab section.

The course is advertised as a potential stand-alone course, but this is simply not the reality. If it truly is meant to be one, then the handouts should be changed to make them more accessible to students viewing the material for the first time.

Additionally, some sections did not include a mini pre-lab lecture before each lab, which I think would make the course more beneficial. Making these pre-lab lectures requirements for TAs of the course (and maybe even described on the syllabus) would allow students to get more out of topic and be better prepared to think through the concepts during the final lab practical.
The content doesn't match up with the lecture course particularly well.
Overall the lab course doesn't follow the timeline of either Physics class very well, which meant a lot of time was spent learning the concepts of the lab because they hadn't been covered yet.

This course definitely helped me to understand lecture material. However, we had to do a lot of stuff in lab way before we were introduced to it in lecture, which made some of the labs pretty confusing and stressful.

Strengths: Straightforward, low work load

Weaknesses: Your enjoyment of the class and understanding of the material really depends on your TA

Strengths: labs were well organized, instructors were clear
Weaknesses: it was at times unclear what was expected from us

The experiments aren't particularly interesting and aren't synced up with the material in the lecture series. This is not necessarily an issue, except the explanation given is pretty rudimentary in the lab handouts (it can't be that much more in-depth), and concepts don't get explained any further in lab.
The lab reports are simple and short, but sometimes I felt that what we were doing was not helping me learn more about physics.

The only merit of this class is that the only outside of lab work is a weekly one page lab summary which is busywork of little educational value or rigor.

The only way I could see this class be improved if it was turned over from Sid Cahn to Adriane Steinacker for a full redesign. Rather than learning about FFT graphs, beat frequencies, waves, and optics, it could actually be used to reinforce and emphasize the electricity and magnetism topics that we learned about in class. 

Also, there was an especially odd somewhat sexual quotation at the end of one of the lab packets that is entirely inappropriate and should be removed.

The major weakness was that it did not correlate well with the things learned in lecture, it was too fast paced and you would have to apply concepts in lab that were not talked about in class, which made it much harder to follow.

The strength of the course isn't it's hands on aspect that allows students to visualize concepts, which makes them easier to grasp and comprehend. The weaknesses of this course are the lack of overlap between the lab and the lecture course. Although PHYS 171 and PHYS 166L were more closely in tune than their predecessors, there is still room for improvement. For example, topics were Simi liar but they were not timed accordingly.
I think the course format is good. Its physics lab and you get out of it what you put in.

Strength: Well-organized and interesting weekly lab experiments that make you appreciate physics.

Weaknesses: N/A
The experiments were interesting to learn and did not take too much time beyond the allotted 3 hour lab session/
I thought it related a lot better to PHYS171 and so I was happy about that because I felt at a disadvantage last semester. I think it's a good class!

Some of the portions of the rubric for lab reports aren't clearly stated as tasks in the lab handouts, and occationally the procedures are confusingly worded. Other than that the course was cleanly structured and overall good!

The labs are reasonably varied, which keeps content changing, but they could get long. Additionally, I felt like the grading of lab reports - particularly the concept of "insight" - was often inconsistent and could be confusing. I did like that the labs were hands-on and often involved building circuits or telescopes or whatever else the lab may have required.
This half of lab was much better than 165L. It is well structured, maybe just make the final more doable because it was very stressful, even with a lot of practice.

Strengths: well-organized and well-run. It's clear that the instructors have refined the class over time so that there aren't too many bumps along the way. Labs are more interesting than the ones from 165 (thankfully no more error propagation). My TA, Emma, was super sweet and helpful every time. Weaknesses: labs were sometimes worded a bit confusingly. There were parts that a lot of people got stuck on because they couldn't interpret what was being said in the lab procedure, which is worth revisiting.
Often very abstract, but very little work outside of class

The teaching fellows and course instructors were all very helpful in guiding us through the labs, especially when we got stuck or were confused by the instructions. In general, the course packets were pretty good EXCEPT the optics packets which were extremely confusing and hard to read. It would have been more helpful in the optics packets (and optics labs) had more examples, such as using the thin lens equation and drawing lens diagrams. The optics packets also appeared to have a lot of information deriving the Snell's Law which we ended up not using at all. Not having to do as much error analysis as 165L was much appreciated though! Weekly lab reports were a good way to summarize and review the material learned each week.

Strengths: the labs are shorter this semester! You could also tell that they tried to make them more relevant for the premeds, who make up 100% of the course. 

Weaknesses: the same dependence of your entire grade on your TA's level of strictness, the same bullshit final, the same tricky quizzes.
It was a nice course! Run by good people and no complaints.
There isn't much to say.  The class teaches basic skills like how to use an oscilloscope, but none of the labs are particularly interesting.
final was really hard, not sure if I felt adequately prepared to take that
It was TOO relevant to premeds.
This course is cool because you learn about circuits and use fascinating technology, it does not coincide with the lecture course well and often times we were left confused as with what to do.

Strengths: One page lab reports, relatively fair quizzes, relatively fair final exam. Weaknesses: Varying expectactions for the lab reports by TA, particularly regarding insight, were the most frustrating aspects of this semesters introductory lab course. Who you have as a TA should not be the determining factor regarding how many points are taken off for insight or other mistakes. This issue could be ameliorated by giving students clear expectations for what to include in the lab reports before writing the first one.  Moreover, the lab got way ahead of the lecture by the middle of the semester, and nothing was done to rectify this. Thus, it would be really helpful if the lab and lecture professors were in constant communication to ensure that students are learning the concepts in lecture before experimenting with them in lab.
This course was fine. Just fine.
This lab taught me about the topics taught in lecture and I really liked the professors. Some of the TA's were sassy.

Strengths: great to take with PHYS 171 and helps understanding of coursework so much
Weaknesses: so difficult when you haven't covered the material in class yet and extremely frustrating when that is the case.
Often quirky and funny in the lab handouts. Overall slightly unbad.

I enjoyed how hands-on the course was and the labs were quite fun. It could be improved further if the lab handouts always clearly delineate (this was almost always the case) what we should write down in the lab report.
I think it could be better if it matched up with the lecture course more.
There wasnt really enough teaching and it seemed as though the TAs and instructors assumed that various things were intuitive when they werent necessarily.

Strengths: Doing things like tinkering around with capacitors and resistors in a circuit can give you a hands on feel to what you are learning about in lecture, TAs are generally very helpful, Professor Barrett is awesome

Weaknesses: The scope of the lab is much more in depth than the lecture and can often leave students feeling lost. The lab was also constantly ahead of the lecture material, so often students came in with no knowledge on the subject, making the labs more mindless, i.e. following steps, than meaningful. Especially in the case of optics, a subject not taught in the lecture, I had a very hard time grounding myself and understanding what was going on. Sometime, less would have felt like more in my opinion.

My main critique is in the way that the final is a practical exam. Throughout the course, we have learned to work in pairs, and in the end, we are made to separate and work under time-sensitive conditions. Frankly, it does not feel like this is at all a good way of testing lab capabilities. In a regular lab, you will always be working with others and collaborating. Of course, this makes it difficult to assess individuals by themselves, but I think just the weekly lab reports are a MUCH better representation of the work done over the course of the semester. The final is extremely stressful for students and feels out of left field in comparison to what we've been doing all semester.

Physics 166L was very difficult for me to follow without any prior experience working with circuits, which is what the first half of the labs revolves around. I wish the class was better tailored to curriculum in Physics 181 or 171 (I took 181 concurrently with the lab) so that it isn't only the students who've already finished learning the material in previous years who can excel. I often relied on my partners to get through the circuits labs, which wasn't ideal for needing to do them alone later on during the final exam.

The strengths of this course were the experiments that focused on circuits and signals. One improvement that could be made to this area would be to connect what we learned about signals and circuits to the real world, such as by exploring radio signals. It would be cool to have a radio signal broadcast within the classroom and giving us an antennae and an appropriate receiving circuit which we could measure with logger pro.

The biggest weakness of this class was the section on optics. I felt it was extremely cursory and not very well explained. We also don't learn anything about optics in physics lecture, so coming to lab and conducting experiments on something we don't understand was very frustrating. I came away from this class with useful knowledge of circuits and signals, but I definitely did not take away any useful knowledge of optics.

One strength was being able to work with partners because talking through the experiments helped us work through them. One weakness is that the final exam did not seem entirely representative of physical knowledge and being unable to perform a specific task could put a bunch of other tasks in jeopardy.

strengths were 1-page writeups instead of full on lab reports....weaknesses were the way the course is structured with the practical final being a great deal of your grade and sometimes poor TAs/teaching
The experiments tend to talk about topics ahead of lecture so the material can be kind of confusing. My TA also wasn't the most experienced with these topics so the labs took a decent amount of time.

As someone with absolutely no background in electronics, I found this course to be very challenging at times. The experiments were not aligned well with lecture, and I was often asked to take quizzes and perform labs on topics that I had never encountered in my previous studies. While this misalignment occurred occasionally in Phys 165, I found that topics in mechanics were much more intuitive and could be grasped merely through the brief lab manuals and via the experiment. In contrast, it was very difficult to understand what a capacitor was and how it worked, for example, without any formal instruction. To improve this course, I would suggest working with the introductory lecture instructors to ensure that lab material is covered in lecture before the week of the experiment. In addition, I would appreciate a very brief (perhaps 5-minute) lecture from the lab TA at the beginning of each lab period to review the concepts of the day's experiment and introduce any unfamiliar material before we take the quiz. I also rarely, if ever, received feedback on my work from my TA.
Finally, I found the final exam, particularly the optics section, to be more challenging than expected. In my opinion, that portion of the exam tested aspects of optics that were not emphasized in the optics lab, unlike the other two sections, which seemed fair given our previous experiences.
The strength of this course was its senior faculty, all of whom were very friendly and knowledgeable teachers and who always went above and beyond to answer my questions thoroughly and in an understandable manner. The workload was reasonable for a half-credit course.
Have it be more applicable to non-mechanical engineering majors. Even as a physics major I didnt feel like any of the material was truly applicable to what Ill be doing.

The labs roughly lined up with the material in the PHYS 170 lecture but could be improved by having them line up more closely so that it was easier to apply the material that had been learned in lecture in lab. My TA Grant was fantastic, very fair, and made the lab a success. In general the labs were useful extensions of the lectures but there needs to be better overlap between the two. Also the final was far too hard compared to the difficulty seen in the rest of the semester.

There truly is not enough space to state weaknesses. The strengths are the enthusiasm of the instructors and of my TA in particular. Without them, there really would have been nothing positive about the experience.
Easy to follow and engaging labs, but they are sometimes not perfectly aligned with PHYS 171 material.
This course went well with PHYS 166L. The lab could have been more synced with the lecture course.
A weakness of this course is that it doesnt align with the lecture course, especially 171.
I felt that sometimes the labs were unnecessarily long at some points.
The course should be better aligned with the physics lecture courses.
I wish there was a midterm exam like in Physics 165L
This course did a great job of facilitating learning and grades/feedback was delivered quickly.

The class readings were a big strength, since they were clear and presented the material in a concise yet explanatory manner. The quizzes were also a good test to make sure we did the readings and be rewarded with points. The labs were sometimes boring but most of them were engaging and entertaining.
Strengths: good intro to E and M

This course helped me understand physics much better than my 181 lecture. The main weakness, however is that the labs are geared towards premeds, so theres too much of a focus on medical applications.
It is a good course that covers a lot of different concepts in sufficient depth.
super boring and didnt learn much at all

Final exam is pretty rough and Im not sure how good of an evaluation it is when there is widespread consensus that people didnt understand 1/3 or more of the exam. I went to the practice sessions 3+ times outside of class which may have helped but I still struggled.
It was hard, but they definitely do a good job of helping you when you ask questions which is nice. Sometimes the lab notes didnt explain fully how to do something though so that could be fixed.

Strengths: very low key in terms of the stuff we have to do outside of lab. This is definitely a half credit, unlike some lab classes that are far too demanding on students. The labs are also really engaging

Weaknesses: unfortunately, i really do think that 166 needs to update the syllabus. The lab delved into optics even though we have zero exposure to that in 181, and i heard 171 had a similar complaint
Very good course with relevant experiments to improve different facets of my understanding of how to use certain equipments.

This lab could really be improved. It was completely out of sync with the PHYS 171 lectures, the experiments were ok but there should be much more guidance in the lab handouts because we had to constantly ask the TA for help and that really doesn't prepare us well for the final exam where you can't ask for help! I also think that having a final for that class is completely pointless and unnecessarily stressful - 3 hours is so little time to complete the 3 experiments and if you mess up on the tiniest step your grade for the whole semester will suffer! Especially since nothing we did over the semester prepared us for working on our own.
It allows hands on access to many different topics in physics, but the grading seems to be designed to take away points for minor details.

The strength is that the instructors are really gun, and excited about physics. The weakness is that the labs are tedious, and don't go in hand with the physics 171 course at all. SO you are learning everything in lab. That can be very frustrating, and unfair. I would suggest making a lab that actually relates to the topics learned in class.
This course was great. It is very organized and easy to understand.

The strengths are the course's reasonable workload and the generally well-written and informative background info given for each experiment. The experiments themselves were designed fairly well and were fairly easy to follow. However, major improvements could be made in terms of the lab's relatedness to lecture material. This is particularly a pacing issue; most weeks' labs covered material that had not yet been covered in lecture (or never would be), which is not fair to the students who struggle because the material is unfamiliar, and not fair to the TFs who have to teach material that they assumed the students would have had some exposure to. Additionally, the final exam environment is high-pressure and fast-paced--two qualities that do not mimic the work generally expected of students up to that point in the course. Therefore, many students (including myself) didn't feel prepared for the final, and found it especially unfair that it was worth so much of the final grade when we had been doing well so far. I found that the midterm exam in 165L was extremely helpful in alleviating some of the final exam anxiety.
The course does not follow the syllabus for the PHYS 181 lecture course very closely, and it would be best if these two courses could coordinate.
really enjoyed this class! great teaching staff and handouts, wished it was more in line with physics 181 material though

One of the weaknesses of the course in my opinion was the lab reports. The guidelines for writing them were fairly vague, and ultimately they all ended up being summaries of our lab notes that we had taken in class. We gained no further insight into the material by writing the reports.

I know it's hard to align the lab course with the physics courses (171 or 181) but it would be so much better if the lab topics weren't one or two weeks before we cover the topics in class. For example, we did optics in lab almost a week or two before we did it in 171. It was difficult to keep up in lab and understand what was going on. My TF didn't really help either, sometimes she didn't even seem to know what was going on.

Strengths- corresponds with material in the lecture course PHYS 171, plenty of help available during labs 
Weaknesses- lab handouts can be written more clearly with more straightforward directions. The bolded fonts used in the early lab handouts was helpful
This course was fine.
This class is very long and monotonous, but as expected for a college physics lab.

This lab is just out of sync with the PHYS 181 lecture course, and the packets don't actually provide enough information for us to understand what we are doing. Just rearranging the labs so that we have learned something before we encounter it would be super helpful. Otherwise, a brief lecture that explains more what is happening physically would be helpful. This is especially true for optics, which I never learned and still do not understand.

The strengths of this course are the TF (Sam), the organization of the lab topics, and the up-to-date equipment available. The weaknesses of this course are the occasional lab exercises (e.g., using an EKG) which seem pointless and more like attempts to appeal to pre-meds than to provide meaningful physics lab instruction.
Too much relies on the practical, a lot of anxiety, ended up crying afterwards. I dont think its the best test to see how much we have learned.
Most of the labs progressed smoothly except for the optics sections, which seemed to come out of nowhere and receive little attention or followup outside of those labs.
Could be aligned more with the physics 171/181 courses it's supposed to go with--content went much better with physics 201; some of the concepts we did in lab were never covered in physics 171/181
The course imitates the first semester in its structure, allowing for an easy flow from one semester to the next. However, the labs can sometimes be very confusing in their descriptions and analysis.
This course's only weakness was that the quizzes occasionally tested factoids rather than concepts.
Weaknesses - The labs did not synchronize with lectures.

The course does not have very clear instructions. The experiments are sometimes difficult to follow, and the lab practical is not a good evaluation tool. The lab write ups were good practice in concisely summarizing experiments.
Some of the labs could have more relevance to the physics course that is taught in parallel.

The instructors are the main strength of this course -- they are always willing to provide a helping hand or a deeper explanation of a topic. The repetitiveness of this course was its main weakness, as the experiments were sometimes not exceedingly different from each other and could begin to feel tedious at times.

The course was honestly very ambitious with many of the concepts it was trying to have students learn for themselves. These concepts often went over our heads due to a lack of background in many of the topics.
The structure of topics and information in lab handouts was helpful and interesting. The lab procedures themselves at times seemed random and were difficult to relate to the topic being investigated.

This course, like most intro classes, covers topics that are not relevant to everyone. As a premed student, I was forced to learn things that did not directly pertain to my interests, but we don't have a choice.

This course does a good making sure that we have multiple opportunities to use the lab equipment.  However, I wish that the lab experiments throughout the semester went more closely along with the topics covered in lecture at the time.

The course was actually quite well-organized and facilitated for student learning. However, examinations proved quite difficult and seemed unfair in relation to what we were expected to know for other labs.
The labs were straight to the point and there wasn't much unnecessary work

The course is not very difficult and there is very little work required outside of class besides the short weekly write-ups.  The labs themselves can go quickly if you are a fast worker or very slowly if you are really putting in an effort to understand everything you are doing.  The experiments for the most part are not very interesting.

If you need to take this course, you will take this course. You will not take this course if you don't have to. That's the way it should be. 

Either way, this is the LEAST painful pre-med lab out of all of them. It is, overall, actually enjoyable!

It's an alright class. It's extremely frustrating sometimes (by virtue of poor/off-topic/rambling explanations on the TA's part, confusing/incomplete introductions to the material in the handouts, disapproving demeanor of instructors), but I do feel like I learned something.

You probably have to take this. That's okay. Out of all the labs at Yale, this one is probably the best one. Be organized, have a plan beforehand, read the handout and you should be fine. Shoutouts to Connor for being an awesome TA.

I would recommend this course to another student, although it will almost always be taken as a requirement. I was actually in the unusual scenario of having taken 205L and choosing to take this course instead of 206L. I don't regret this decision, since I didn't have the time for 206L, but having already taken 205L made this class very easy.
I would not recommend this course, unless it was required.
If you're taking this class it's for a pre-req or major requirement.
Yes! Sid was an amazing professor and made learning in the lab enjoyable!
Only if you need to take it.
I would recommend it, a great complement to PHYS 171.
I would not recommend this course to another student unless required.
no
You know if you have to take it.
Yes; it's a great supplement to lecture and not taking lab last semester I found I understood concepts better in class by seeing them in lab.

This class isn't fun, but if you have to take it it's not too bad. I found it to be pretty stressful mainly because of the final exam, which is super tough conceptually in a way that there is no real way to prepare for.
You're taking it because you have to

Actually, yes - for pre-med students this is a pretty nice lab. Everyone is friendly, and there is no atmosphere of competition that is unfortunately present in other labs/courses. The material is quite interesting and presented well.
It's an easy but boring lab.
Not in a million years
If you are taking it, you need to.
Nobody is opting to take this class because they are interested or actually want to take it (it's either a major requirement or a pre-med requirement).
It is an alright lab class to take with physics, not bad at all and much better than either chem lab. If you are taking it, it's because you have to and it's fine.
No, I wouldn't recommend the course unless you love physics, need it for your major, or are pre-med.
You have to take it if youre taking it. Its not that bad and the experiments are pretty cool!
Yes, in my opinion, this is a better physics lab than PHYS 165L (which was already pretty good). Very chill lab that still gets you to learn cool new things about Physics.
Yes. You can't really go wrong with Physics Lab. You learn a lot and the experiments are cool.
I would recommend it but you probably just need to take it for a major. Otherwise why would you take it?

You're not going to take this if you don't have to, but if you do have to take a physics lab, I would recommend this one. The lab reports consist of a one page "summary and afterthoughts" that takes maybe a half hour to write, and most of the labs only took an hour or two. Definitely more painless than other labs.

I would only recommend this course to a student who is really interested in physics and in practicing those concepts. Otherwise, I would say people should only take this course if they have to, as it is a significant block of time, requires quite a bit of investment, and can sometimes get long and somewhat dull.
Most people don't take this unless they have to- don't take it for fun but if you have to, it's not bad! One of the better lab courses.

Yes! This class was a lot of fun. We got to play with and explore a ton of concepts that we only get to hear about in physics lecture. Professor Cahn is greathes incredibly knowledgeable, funny, and also a great teacher. The TAs are also fantastic, and really deepen our understanding of the material. I took physics lab 205 before taking 166, and HIGHLY recommend 166. 166 is by far the better structured, more engaging, and less  work intensive of the two classes.

Yes! Lab reports only take 1-2 hours a week, you can get out of lab early if you're efficient, and the labs themselves are more interesting than the ones in 165. Final is kind of hard. The TA I had, Emma C, was super sweet and helpful, so get her if you can!
Unless you need it, not worth it

The teaching fellows and course instructors were all very helpful in guiding us through the labs, especially when we got stuck or were confused by the instructions. In general, the course packets were pretty good EXCEPT the optics packets which were extremely confusing and hard to read. It would have been more helpful in the optics packets (and optics labs) had more examples, such as using the thin lens equation and drawing lens diagrams. The optics packets also appeared to have a lot of information deriving the Snell's Law which we ended up not using at all. Not having to do as much error analysis as 165L was much appreciated though! Weekly lab reports were a good way to summarize and review the material learned each week.

The only people who take this course are premed and they don't get a choice, so this question is a little irrelevant. What I will say is that I did not enjoy this course as much as I did 165L. Even though these labs are much more relevant to medicine, I felt they were very disconnected and confusing. I never understood what we were doing and it felt like a lot of random electronics stuff. Also, I struggled a bit more because my TA was much more strict that my previous one when it came to grading.
If you need to take it, it's pretty chill. Way easier and less demanding than the chem labs.
It does what it needs to.
Didn't love the class, but would not tell others to actively avoid it. Basically, it's ok.
If you have to take it, take it
I would recommend it to a student if they must take it. It isn't really something that you can just take for enjoyment, you need it for requirements.
I would recommend this course with caution. Pick your lab day/instructor wisely, as some instructors provide clearer explanations than others.
Don't take it unless you have to.
This lab taught me about the topics taught in lecture and I really liked the professors. I would recommend.

No, I wouldn't. Take it if you have to. Its boring and time consuming and confusing. The final is stressful, and labs week to week are not very well written, contributing to a general feeling of unpreparedness that I carried with me through the class.
Only take this course if you have to.

Take it if premed / required. Also it is surprisingly quite fun and enjoyable. There are clear real-world implications for things like Fourier transform, RC circuits, optics etc. If you can draw some real-world connections it could actually help you understand the physical world a little better.
If you have to take it, might as well immerse yourself in it and have fun. The labs were quite fun and they help you build a lot of hands on skills.
I would recommend this course to another student because it is a good introduction to physics, but with hands on experience.
No. Dont take it unless you have to. Very tedious and you dont learn much.

If you have to take the class, then do it. The regular lab are usually quite fair and graded well. The lab reports are quick and painless, especially in comparison to general chemistry and even organic chemistry. You do not have to do too much work in preparation each week. All the TAs I've had are kind, and Professor Barrett is spectacular. Most of the labs are interesting, and it is fun to tinker with circuits and things. The course does tend to run ahead of the lecture, so you will have to do labs on things you do not know anything about which can be frustrating, and in the end, you will do some labs on optics, which is not taught in the general physics sequence. Things start to get messy at the final, which I think is a very stressful and an inaccurate way of testing students. Essentially, you do 3 labs in 3 hours by yourself with some multiple choice questions, and this makes up a huge percentage of your final grade. It just feels like since we've worked as partners throughout the semester, the final does not represent the rest of the course well. Most people came into it feeling like their whole grade could change based on those 3 hours, and I do not think that it is a good way of assessing students. 

However, if you like this material, go for it! If you just want to maybe try a lab for fun, probably not a great idea.

You're probably taking Physics 166L because you have to, but if you're just considering it for a science credit, then make sure you're comfortable with working with circuits if you want an easier time.

This is a standard physics lab and you're probably taking it as a requirement. It's a good class and similar to 165, just know the material is slightly more difficult to grasp conceptually. Beware the unit on optics: it's not covered in lecture and makes those experiments rather painful.
Yes, it helped me understand topics in physics 2 that were important to lecture.
not if you don't have to
Yes, it is a good lab.

Yes, this is a good introductory physics lab course. I would recommend this lab option over the other choices available. The instructional staff is excellent, and the course is well organized with a manageable workload. The final exam can be challenging.
Only take it if you have to
Required if you are pre-med, the workload is not too bad and while the final can be challenging, if you have a good TA this class is not too bad and is a useful extension of the lecture.
No. You only take this course if you must, and if there is any way to avoid, I implore you to do so.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in introductory physics, engineering, or medicine.
Only if you have to.
If it is necessary to take for your major, then yes take it.
This is a good introduction to circuits and magnetism
absolutely -- super easy course, really light workload, 20 min lab reports at most, finish lab in an hour each week, but the final exam is hella difficult
Take it if you have to, it's pretty chill.
Absolutely. It is a fun course and not too much work. Definitely enhances your understanding of the material, especially for Physics 171.
Yes, I would recommend this class to a student who wants to see how the concepts learned in the lecture course can be applied to our everyday lives.
If you have to take it, take it. Its a good into to E and M, and some of the concepts you learn help with Phys 181.
Yes, it's a doable intro physics lab that teaches you a lot and isn't stressful.
Take it if youre premed. better than first semester.
Not really. Avoid if possible. Experience is very TA dependent. For example some TAs were more generous answering questions on final
If you're taking this lab, you probably need it. It's not terrible but I think your experience really depends on your TA. The instructors are all really nice.
If you have to take it, you have to take it. Not too bad though.

if you didn't take 165L for some reason, don't be afraid to take this one. You'll have a little catching up to do logistically but the lab is very easy to get caught up on. this is a pretty chill lab class compared to others a premed might take like gen chem or even orgo lab
If you have to take it, then you will have to take it. It's not a course I look forward to every Wednesday, but it's a good course to teach you skills.
Take it if you need to. It's not a particularly enjoyable lab even though the reports are really short and the labs 3 hours or less.
Take it if it is part of requirement for med school or major.
I mean I only took it because I was pre-med, and I knew that it couldnt be worse than Physics Lab 1 with Bonnie Fleming ( she is mean and also never saw her expect during the exam)
No
Absolutely take this class if you are an engineering major looking for a physics lab pre req. The workload is really light and the class is very enjoyable.

The lab does help to make some electricity concepts tangible, and the week-to-week work is pretty painless up to the point of the final exam. Most people take it as some sort of requirement, so generally not a waste of time and will probably be somewhat helpful. I didn't dread coming to lab!
it's a prereq, won't eat up too much of your week
This course is low stress with low a workload and relatively straightforward and easy. I would recommend.

You're probably taking physics lab because it's a requirement, so you have to take it whether you want to or not. It's not bad in terms of workload (a one page lab write up every week, final practical exam) and I hear it's easier than the other physics lab class. Your experience in this class kind of depends on the TF that you get, because some are better teachers than others.
Only if you have to
I would not recommend this class to another student unless it is a requirement. It is a very long lab, and fairly boring. The final practical is very difficult as well.
I mean you probably have to take it and its not the worst

I would recommend this course to anyone looking for a nice supplementary lab course to PHYS 171/181. The lab often introduces concepts earlier than lecture, which gives you a chance to understand lecture material in a hands-on environment.
yes, it's somewhat interesting and not very hard; it's a good way to get practical experience with circuits
If you have to take it, take it. Its fine. Interesting subject matter and Ive to have hands on experience. Take it with 171 if you can because there is a better correlation of material.
Unless necessary for a requirement, I would not suggest taking this course.
Yes, if you're taking Phys 171 and need it for whatever reason (pre-med, etc.)

Yes this class is great. And yes, you're probably taking it because it's required and not because you want to, but you'll have a good time all the same. The material is interesting and the expectations and assignments are very clear.
Unless it is mandatory, I would not recommend taking this lab course. You are honestly better off just watching YouTube physics lab videos online.
Only take if required, as you will not gain a lot of insight.

I would recommend this course to another student, especially if they wanted a useful course to take concurrently with the physics lecture classes. It is not terribly difficult and I feel like I learned a lot from this course.

I would not recommend this course to another student. Other than how to use a few tools, I don't feel like I gained a lot of knowledge from the course, even though I did try my best to understand the topics beforehand.
Yes, a great physics lab for anyone in physics.
yes, it's a requirement for lots of things
I would recommend this course to another student.  Conducting the lab experiments allows for better understanding of the various physical concepts.
It's a requirement most of the time.
Yes because it teaches you useful knowledge,
Since the experiments are mostly not very exciting or cool, this isn't a fun class to take if you do not need it to fulfill a requirement.
